G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 19A.proposition: The Lynn District Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A, and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The Lynn District Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A, and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2 & 8.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 2 & 8, because the cause of action arose in Essex County, at the Premises located in Lynn, Massachusetts, and Defendant owns and operates real property in this county.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Massachusetts law imposes upon landlords and property owners a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain common areas in a reasonably safe condition for tenants and lawful visitors.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is a leading Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care owed by occupiers of land to all lawful visitors. While the provided excerpt is a concurrence focused on trespassers, the majority opinion clearly establishes that landowners must exercise reasonable care to keep premises (including common areas) reasonably safe for tenants and other lawful visitors. Thus the case is proper authority for the stated Massachusetts duty.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: “We hold, therefore, that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees should be abolished in this Commonwealth. The duty of care owed by an occupier of land should not depend on the status of the person who enters, but on whether in the management of his property he has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others… Henceforth in this Commonwealth the standard of care owed by the occupier of land will be the standard of reasonable care in all the circumstances.”

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes upon landlords and property owners a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain common areas in a reasonably safe condition for tenants and lawful visitors.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.support_reasoning: The court squarely states the Massachusetts common-law duty of landowners toward lawful visitors, including the obligation to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition. Although the main holding concerns the absence of a duty to alter an adjacent state highway, the opinion expressly affirms the general landlord/property-owner duty described in the proposition, citing prior Massachusetts cases. Thus, it is accurate authority for the stated general rule, even though the plaintiff ultimately loses on a narrower issue of highway-related duty.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: Landlords are liable for injuries resulting from their failure to keep common areas in as safe a condition as that in which they were, or appeared to be, at the start of the tenancy, and must use reasonable care to protect tenants against foreseeable risks.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly abandons the old status-based rules and holds that landlords, like other persons, must exercise reasonable care to avoid subjecting others to unreasonable risk of harm, including on demised premises. It also reaffirms that, as to common areas, the landlord’s duty is to maintain them in a condition not less safe than at the time of letting, and extends a general negligence standard tied to foreseeability and reasonable care. Thus the case directly supports the proposition about liability for failure to keep common areas safe and the duty to protect tenants from foreseeable risks.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt:
“The landlord ‘was under a separate and limited duty toward each tenant and that tenant’s visitors to exercise reasonable care to maintain the common areas in a condition not less safe than they were, or appeared to be in, at the time of the letting to the particular tenant.’ King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658, 660 (1977)…

‘Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’”}

Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322 (2006).proposition: Landlords are liable for injuries resulting from their failure to keep common areas in as safe a condition as that in which they were, or appeared to be, at the start of the tenancy, and must use reasonable care to protect tenants against foreseeable risks.
Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition describes a general tort duty of landlords to keep common areas as safe as at the start of the tenancy and to use reasonable care to protect tenants from foreseeable risks. Humphrey v. Byron does not adopt or apply such a rule; instead, it expressly declines to extend the Young v. Garwacki residential duty to commercial landlords and reaffirms the narrower commercial rule that liability exists only if the landlord contracted to repair and did so negligently, or if the defect is in a common area under the landlord’s control. Thus, the case does not support the broad duty stated in the proposition.
Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today leaves intact the rule that ‘a lessor of commercial premises is liable in tort for personal injuries only if either (1) he contracted to make repairs and made them negligently, or (2) the defect that caused the injury was in a “common area,” or other area appurtenant to the leased area, over which the lessor had some control.’ Chausse v. Coz, 405 Mass. 264, 266 (1989).”

Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.raw_text: Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515 (1st Cir. 1990) (applying Massachusetts law)
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.proposition: Negligence under Massachusetts law consists of a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, a breach of that duty, causation (both cause‑in‑fact and proximate cause), and actual damages.
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the elements of a negligence cause of action and does so while applying Massachusetts law. It identifies duty, breach, proximate/legal cause (which it further breaks down into foreseeability, cause‑in‑fact, and substantial factor), and actual damage or injury, matching the proposition’s formulation of duty, breach, causation (cause‑in‑fact and proximate cause), and actual damages.
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.relevant_excerpt: "In any negligence cause of action, there are four elements on which plaintiffs must adduce adequate evidence to prevail. Plaintiffs must show: (1) a legal duty owed by defendant to plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) proximate or legal cause; and (4) actual damage or injury. See W. Prosser & W. Keeton, The Law of Torts Sec. 30 (5th ed. 1985); see also Quinones, 492 F.2d at 1274."

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Negligence under Massachusetts law consists of a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, a breach of that duty, causation (both cause‑in‑fact and proximate cause), and actual damages.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The court explicitly describes what the plaintiffs must prove to prevail on their negligence claims and identifies the required elements, including breach of duty, causation, and actual loss (damages). While it does not separately label proximate vs. cause‑in‑fact, its reference to causation as an essential element and citation to Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 are consistent with the standard Massachusetts formulation that negligence consists of duty, breach, causation, and damages. Thus, the opinion supports the proposition at the level of general elements of negligence.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

Carter v. Yardley & Co., 319 Mass. 92 (1.proposition: Plaintiff was a foreseeable member of the class of persons to be protected by the fire safety statutes and regulations governing smoke detectors in residential buildings.
Carter v. Yardley & Co., 319 Mass. 92 (1.support_reasoning: The case concerns a manufacturer’s tort duty to remote purchasers of a defective product (perfume) and the abolition of the privity requirement. It does not involve, interpret, or apply fire safety statutes, regulations, or smoke detectors, nor does it analyze whether a plaintiff is within a statutorily protected class. Any foreseeability discussion here is in the context of common-law negligence for product defects, not statutory fire-safety protections, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Carter v. Yardley & Co., 319 Mass. 92 (1.relevant_excerpt: "Plainly the defendant, when it manufactured and bottled its perfume, including the bottle in question, and put it into the channels of trade, expected that those channels would carry each bottle into the hands of some ultimate consumer who would be likely to apply the contents to her skin. If any bottle should contain a harmful ingredient, injury to some unknown consumer rather than to a middleman or retailer must have been anticipated."

MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.,.raw_text: MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp., 394 Mass. 131 (1985)
MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.,.proposition: Plaintiff was a foreseeable member of the class of persons to be protected by the fire safety statutes and regulations governing smoke detectors in residential buildings.
MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns products liability and a drug manufacturer’s duty to warn users of oral contraceptives. It does not involve fire safety statutes, smoke detectors, residential buildings, or foreseeability of a class protected by such statutes. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the proposition about smoke-detector fire safety statutes and foreseeable plaintiffs.
MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.,.relevant_excerpt: “This products liability action raises the question of the extent of a drug manufacturer’s duty to warn consumers of dangers inherent in the use of oral contraceptives. … The narrow issue, on appeal, is whether, as the plaintiffs contend, a manufacturer of birth control pills owes a direct duty to the consumer to warn her of the dangers inherent in the use of the pill. We conclude that such a duty exists under the law of this Commonwealth.”

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7 26F.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 148, § 26F, and related provisions, certain residential buildings must be equipped with approved smoke detectors in accordance with regulations promulgated by the State Fire Marshal and applicable building and fire codes.

780 CMR.proposition: The Massachusetts State Building Code (780 CMR), as in effect at the relevant time, and the State Fire Code (527 CMR and now 527 CMR 1.00), require the installation and maintenance of smoke detection systems in multifamily dwellings, including in common hallways, and require that such systems be kept in proper working order.

527 CMR and now 527 CMR 1.00.proposition: The Massachusetts State Building Code (780 CMR), as in effect at the relevant time, and the State Fire Code (527 CMR and now 527 CMR 1.00), require the installation and maintenance of smoke detection systems in multifamily dwellings, including in common hallways, and require that such systems be kept in proper working order.

G.L. c. 143, \u00a7 3.proposition: G.L. c. 143, § 3 and G.L. c. 148, §§ 26A‑26F place duties on building owners to comply with fire safety provisions and authorize enforcement of requirements concerning smoke detectors and other life‑safety systems.

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7\u00a7 26A\u201126F.proposition: G.L. c. 143, § 3 and G.L. c. 148, §§ 26A‑26F place duties on building owners to comply with fire safety provisions and authorize enforcement of requirements concerning smoke detectors and other life‑safety systems.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358‑59 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s violation of statutes and regulations designed to protect tenants’ safety, including fire and building codes, constitutes evidence of negligence and may support liability where such violation is causally related to the plaintiff’s injury.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion does address the effect of a statutory violation on negligence, but it does so in a limiting way rather than in the expansive way stated in the proposition. The court reiterates that violation of a safety statute (here G.L. c. 138, § 69) is only “some evidence” of negligence, does not create an independent basis for civil liability, and does not by itself establish a breach of duty. The case therefore does not stand for the broader idea that such violations ‘may support liability’ simply when causally related; it insists that common-law negligence—including proof of breach—must still be independently established.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “While a violation of c. 138, § 69, carries criminal penalties, the statute does not expressly or implicitly grant an independent ground for civil liability…. It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se…. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent.”

St. Germaine v. Pendergast, 411 Mass. 61.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s violation of statutes and regulations designed to protect tenants’ safety, including fire and building codes, constitutes evidence of negligence and may support liability where such violation is causally related to the plaintiff’s injury.
St. Germaine v. Pendergast, 411 Mass. 61.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that violations of statutes and regulations, including the State Building Code and related safety rules, do not create a new cause of action or negligence per se, but "are only some evidence of negligence." It further explains that such provisions "could be considered as evidence of negligence" with respect to existing common-law duties. This directly supports the proposition that code violations designed to protect safety may constitute evidence of negligence and may support liability when causally connected to the injury, while clarifying they are not automatic liability.
St. Germaine v. Pendergast, 411 Mass. 61.relevant_excerpt: “We do not construe a safety statute to establish a new civil cause of action without express terms or clear legislative intent to that effect… Nor do violations of a statute or regulations constitute negligence per se; they are only some evidence of negligence. … The various provisions of the State Building Code and other rules and regulations relied upon by the plaintiffs could be considered as evidence of negligence with regard to duties imposed by common law on Pendergast….”

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2011127L.proposition: Massachusetts law also obligates landlords to maintain residential premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: Massachusetts law also obligates landlords to maintain residential premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code.

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The duty to maintain safe egress and fire‑safety systems is part of the landlord’s obligation to keep the premises “fit for human habitation.”
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly treats provision of adequate heat and hot water, and compliance with the State Sanitary Code, as part of the landlord’s obligation under the implied warranty of habitability, but it does not specifically address egress or fire‑safety systems. While one might infer that all Sanitary/Building Code–mandated life-safety elements are components of habitability, this case itself focuses on heat, hot water, and general code compliance, not on a distinct duty to maintain safe egress or fire‑safety systems. Thus it is indirect and not strong authority for the precise proposition stated.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “[A] lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition… A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. … [T]he landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes. Whether the scope of the warranty is broader is an open question.” (citations omitted).

Hemingway v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1.proposition: The duty to maintain safe egress and fire‑safety systems is part of the landlord’s obligation to keep the premises “fit for human habitation.”
Hemingway v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1.support_reasoning: The concurrence/dissent explicitly ties the landlord’s obligation of habitability to compliance with statutory and code‑based minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, which include safety obligations like maintaining buildings and egress in a non‑dangerous condition. Justice Quirico argues that these housing statutes, ordinances, and codes "prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units" impose on the landlord, for the benefit of tenants, an obligation to comply with those standards as part of making the premises fit for human habitation. While fire‑safety and egress are not singled out by name in this excerpt, the opinion’s reasoning treats statutory safety and structural requirements as part of the landlord’s habitability obligation, so the case supports the general proposition at a moderate level of specificity.
Hemingway v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1.relevant_excerpt: Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code... The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation. It does so in great detail... It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units. ... I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards...

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for all damages proximately caused by its negligence.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.support_reasoning: The Payton decision concerns whether Massachusetts recognizes certain causes of action (e.g., negligent infliction of emotional distress without physical harm, prenatal injury, and DES market‑share liability) and how damages are conceptualized in a very specific context (including barring recovery where the plaintiff would not have been born but for DES). It does not set out or reaffirm any general rule that a defendant is liable for “all damages proximately caused by its negligence.” The opinion assumes negligence and causation for purposes of the certified questions but does not discuss the scope of damages or articulate a general proximate-cause damages rule, so it cannot be cited as authority for that broad proposition.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.relevant_excerpt: "We note initially that neither the issue of negligence nor that of causation is before us. The certified question assumes both that the defendants were negligent, and that their negligence caused the plaintiffs' emotional distress."

Poole v. Classic Yacht Co., 396 Mass. 1.raw_text: Poole v. Classic Yacht Co., 396 Mass. 1 (1985)
Poole v. Classic Yacht Co., 396 Mass. 1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for all damages proximately caused by its negligence.
Poole v. Classic Yacht Co., 396 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a dissent focused narrowly on evidentiary issues regarding the collateral source rule and the trial judge’s discretion in excluding collateral source evidence. It does not address the general scope of tort damages or state that a defendant is liable for all damages proximately caused by its negligence. Thus, this opinion, particularly the dissent, does not establish or affirm the broad damages principle claimed in the proposition.
Poole v. Classic Yacht Co., 396 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: Collateral source evidence has been deemed irrelevant because “the receipts from the outside source do not go to reduce the defendant’s liability; yet jurors might be led by the irrelevancy to consider plaintiffs’ claims unimportant or trivial or to refuse plaintiffs’ verdicts or reduce them, believing that otherwise there would be unjust double recovery.” Goldstein v. Gontarz, 364 Mass. 800, 809 (1974).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B & 6C.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover from Defendant all compensatory damages allowable by law, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages and diminished earning capacity, damage to personal property, pain and suffering, emotional distress, loss of enjoyment of life, and any other damages proven at trial, together with interest and costs.

Rule 38 of the Massachusetts Rules of Ci.raw_text: Rule 38 of the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure
Rule 38 of the Massachusetts Rules of Ci.proposition: Pursuant to Rule 38 of the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure and applicable law, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
